title: 104_s2189
content: The Act titled "Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute Administrative Systems Act of 1996" aims to provide culturally sensitive experiences and relevant curricula at the institute. It grants greater autonomy to the Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute while keeping it part of the Bureau of Indian Affairs to enhance academic programs. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "institute" refers to the Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute in Albuquerque, New Mexico. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 4. PERSONNEL MANAGEMENT. The Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute in Albuquerque, New Mexico is exempt from certain civil service laws regarding classification, pay, and leave. The president of the institute can establish alternative personnel management provisions to ensure effective administration. The president of the Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute in Albuquerque, New Mexico can establish personnel management regulations in consultation with the governing body, subject to specific requirements and approval by the Secretary. Basic pay rates are capped at the maximum payable for grade GS-15 of the General Schedule. The president of the Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute in Albuquerque, New Mexico can establish personnel management regulations, with basic pay rates capped at the maximum payable for grade GS-15 of the General Schedule. The limitation under section 5307 of title 5, United States Code, shall apply with necessary modifications under alternative personnel management provisions. Procedures for grievance resolution, employee discharge, and notification of employment agreement renewal are established under this section. Employee rights and due process are ensured, with exceptions for probationary employees. The section outlines that existing labor-management provisions, including collective-bargaining agreements, will continue to be recognized until altered or amended by law. It also clarifies that certain provisions do not affect equal employment opportunity, Indian preference, veterans' preference, or eligibility for federal employee benefits. The Act ensures that existing labor-management provisions will be recognized until changed by law. It also specifies that certain matters regulated under the Act are not subject to collective bargaining, except for leave-related issues. The effective date for alternative personnel management provisions will be within one year of the Act's enactment. The Act specifies that alternative personnel management provisions will apply to all applicants and employees of the institute, with current employees exempt unless they voluntarily elect to be covered. The Act specifies alternative personnel management provisions for all institute applicants and employees, with current employees exempt unless they elect to be covered within a 5-year period. The election must be made following specific procedures and is irrevocable. Transition provisions include annual and sick leave for individuals making the election or those affected after the specified effective date. Employees who are transferred, promoted, or reappointed to an institute position from a noninstitute position within the Federal Government or the government of the District of Columbia, without a break in service of 3 days or longer, will retain their annual and sick leave credits from their previous position. Upon termination, any remaining annual leave will be liquidated. Upon termination of employment with the institute, any remaining annual leave will be liquidated in accordance with relevant regulations. Sick leave credits will be creditable for civil service retirement purposes. Transfer of remaining leave upon transfer, promotion, or reemployment is allowed for institute employees moving to a position in the Federal Government or the government of the District of Columbia under a different leave system. Leave earned or accrued under institute regulations is not creditable for civil service retirement purposes. The regulations under this section allow for the transfer of leave to an individual's credit in the employing agency. Work-study students are not covered by this section. The Secretary can delegate procurement authority to the institute's president, subject to applicable law and funding availability. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal year 1997 and beyond, including funds from previous years and additional sums as needed for institute operations.
